citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, there was one tan colored ewe in the sheep and goat enclosure that was identified as needing
veterinary care. The animal had a noticeable increase in respiratory effort, and each breath was easily heard audibly.
These breaths were heard standing up to 10 feet away from the animal. The animal was in good body condition and did
not appear lethargic. When asked if the animal had been seen by a veterinarian, the facility representative stated that they
had noticed the harsh breathing sounds coming from the ewe, but the veterinarian had not yet been contacted about the
issue. The attending veterinarian was contacted during the inspection and they stated that they had been at the facility
one month prior to examine, vaccinate, and deworm the animals, and they had not noticed any respiratory signs at that
time. They confirmed that they had not been contacted about this ewe, and that the clinical signs described sound like
something they would want to be notified of. Failure to seek proper diagnosis and treatment for disease may result in pain
to the animal, worsening of the condition, and possible spread of disease to additional animals if the condition is
contagious. The licensee must communicate with the attending veterinarian to evaluate this animal and determine an
appropriate plan for diagnosis and treatment. To be corrected by August 22, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
At the time of inspection, there was one tan colored ewe in the sheep and goat enclosure that was identified as needing 
veterinary care. The animal had a noticeable increase in respiratory effort, and each breath was easily heard audibly. 
These breaths were heard standing up to 10 feet away from the animal. The animal was in good body condition and did 
not appear lethargic. When asked if the animal had been seen by a veterinarian, the facility representative stated that they 
had noticed the harsh breathing sounds coming from the ewe, but the veterinarian had not yet been contacted about the 
issue. The attending veterinarian was contacted during the inspection and they stated that they had been at the facility 
one month prior to examine, vaccinate, and deworm the animals, and they had not noticed any respiratory signs at that 
time. They confirmed that they had not been contacted about this ewe, and that the clinical signs described sound like 
something they would want to be notified of. Failure to seek proper diagnosis and treatment for disease may result in pain 
to the animal, worsening of the condition, and possible spread of disease to additional animals if the condition is 
contagious. The licensee must communicate with the attending veterinarian to evaluate this animal and determine an 
appropriate plan for diagnosis and treatment. To be corrected by August 22, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
